div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, APRIL 17, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Scakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor,(for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

Chapman, will be sold at Villa El-Oezlha, Ghezirah. The above comprise:- Bedrooms, dining rooms, office, drawing room, kitchen and pantry, Sundries. On view three days before the sale. For detailed catalogues apply to A. &M. Samuelson Bros., Sharia el EGhenech Ezbekish. Terms Cash. 5o/o on the purchase money will be charged to the buyers as auctioneers' fees. div.head: Congo and Nile
div.p: From the standpoint of international amity, says the ’ Globe,” it is satisfactory to learn that come progress has been made towards freeing the Upper Nile from the military introduction of the Congo State. It was profound mistake to have over accorded British Munition for the establishment of foreign influence on any portion of the great waterway. The Congo State possesses a big and fairly navigable river of its own, connecting directly with the sea, and no pretence could be made that the free nee of the Nile was essential for commercial development Bat at the time when permission was given, there was keen rivalry between the Great Powers in befriending the infant State, which was expected to transform an enormous area of savage territory in the Dark Continent It was a further part of the humour of the mom»t to view Belgium, the creator of the Congo State, as possessed by the finest and most enduring intentions for the benefit of the Congoese. But recent disclosures exploded that supposition, while it became more and more, manifest that England should never have opened the door for Europeon intrigue and aggrandisement on the Uppor Nile. That dangerous entrance is to be dosed, we are glad to see, m soon m possible, and by way of earnest, the Congo State has already consented - not without considerable pressure—to give np many of the posts it had secured on the *■ river. Its Government fought hard for their permanent retention, and even, we believe, advanced claims going considerably farther- Bat when "persuasion” took the inconvenient form of stopping the transport of Congoese trade down the Nile, it was recognised at Brussels that some less risky and more profitable arrangement weald have to be come to. If should boa lesson to England to shun sickly sentimentality in the con- duct of Imperial affairs; there is never any real need for its introduction.

div.head: The Patriarchate of Jerusalem
div.p: Ever since the death of Mgr. Piavi, more than a year ago, the Patriarchate of Jerusalem has remained vacant, bat it is hoped that the post will be filled before long. The Pope will probably make the appointment himself, as for some time past Jerusalem has been the scene of a keen political straggle. The quarrels that have ocurred between the Latin and the Oriental Churches have led to the intervention of the Powers on more than one occasion, notably of Franco and Russia. At the Vatican France has been accused, especially since the Franco-Russian Alliance, of neglecting the interests of her proteges in Jerusalem, for fear of arousing the susceptibilities of her ally, with the result that Italy and Germany have taken her place m the protecting Powers of the Latin Christians. The Law of Separation has naturally driven the Vatican to support Italy in her straggle with France for supremacy in Jerusalem, and it is probable that the future Patriarch will be an Italian, - and at any rate not a Frenchman. The Patriarch in the supervision of the I*tin clergy in the Holy City, most of whom until recently were Francoiscans. But of late years other orders have established themselves in Palestine, and the Francoidoans naturally resent the rivalry of these newcomers who have been erecting each.caries and organising pilgrimages' on their own aooonnt. The other orders object to having a Franciscan as Patriarch, u they say that he will favour his own order, and it is thought that Father Genoochi, who has lived for several years at Constantinople, will be appointed. But the Franciscan inflasnce is very strong with the Pope, and so it is possible that one of them will be appointed, in spite of their French sympathies.

div.head: Egyptian Statues For British Museum
div.p: Important additions have just been made to the Department of Egyptian Antiquities at the British Museum. Chief among these are three statues of Usertosen III., about B.C. 9400, representing the king at three different periods of his life—in yunth, in middle age, 4nd m an old man with sunken cheeks. The figures, which are of grey granite, measure a., little over five feet in height, and show the king wearing the characteristic Egyptian apron upon which is inscribed his name in hieroglyphic*. There is also a colossal limestone figure of Amenophis I., about B.C. 1700, representing the king m the god Osiris, wearing the red and white crown, the emblem oi Upper and Lower Egypt On the back of the statue is a portion of an inscription, which reads : "Amenhetep, beloved of Amen, Lord of the thrones of the two hands, giving life.” Objects of later date are two inscribed lids of stone sarcophagi and the south wall of a shrine of one of the Candace queens (B.C. 100—52). This shrine was discovered on the Island of Merce about two years ago,. and has been recently cleared out by Mr. Scott-Mouorief, of the British Museum. The north wall was been set np in the museum at Rhartoum, and the south wall, now re-emoted in the Egyptian sculpture gallery, was presented to the British Museum by the Sirdar.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: "Fairhaven.” f The account of the ceremony of laying the foundation stone of the new House of Rest for Missionaries in Ramleh is held over until tomorrow for want of space. Another Death from Intoxication. A native of Cairo was found dead at Sharia el Maghsal, Cairo, two days ago, and his body was taken to hospital, where the post-mortem examination showed that death was doe to intoxication. Another discovery of antiquities was recently made at Fakous. International Rowing Club. The committee of the Canottieri Alessandria for 1906-7 has been formed as follows: C. E. Mieli, president; A. Egyptian Engineering Co. The Cairo Electric Railway and Heliopolis Oases Company have placed an order for two turbo alternating generator fete of from 1800- 2250 kilowatts each, with Messrs. Brown Boveri & Co., Ltd., of Baden, whose sole agents in Egypt are the Egyptian Engineering Company, Limited. The Cairo Tramways has also placed an order with Messrs. Brown Boveri & Co., Ltd., for four continuous current generators of 750 kilowatts each, for direct coupling to steam turbines. Alexandria Municipal Library. The Municipal Library at Alexandria has acquired a number of works since March 15, of which the following are the most important :—“Dictionnaire da commerce et de la banque,” (Yveo Guyot), “Egyptiens et Anglais” (Mustafa Paoha Kamel). Chantre), “The ancient raoes of the Thebaid” (Maolver Randall), "StielerV Hand Atlas” (1905 edition), "The Making of Modern Egypt” (Sir Auckland Colvin), “A History of Egypt” (J. H- Breadstead\ ' Encyclopedia, etc.” (Diderot and D’Alembert). “The Medical Diseases of Egypt” (F. M. Sandwith), "La nouvelle Egypte” (A. B. de Gnerville), "From Pharaoh to Fellah” (C. F. div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. H. Princess Nazli Hanem Fadel left yesterday afternoon for Tunis, where she will spend the summer season. Lord and Lady Meath and Sir Tatton and Lady Sykes were among the passengers for Europe yesterday by the S. S. Schleswig. Bernard Pacha, Financial Secretary to the Sudan Government, and said Bey Shukeir left yesterday evening for Khartoum. Mrs. Gould regrets that her dance, fixed for Friday, 20th inst., is unavoidably postponed. M. Michel Baklians, an official of the Roumanian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, has been appointed Roumanian Consul-General in Cairo. Mr. Charles Blackstone Clapcott, judge in Assiout Native Tribunal of First Instance, has been delegated as inspector on the Committee of Judicial Surveillance. H H. the Khedive has conferred the rank of Mirmiran on Hassan Hares Pacha, ex- Moudir of the Behera, on the occasion of his retirement, and that of Commander (3rd class) of the Order of the Medjidieh on Choukri Bey, formerly judge of the Native Tribunal of 1st Instance in Alexandria. Ali Bey Rasmi, inspector of the 2nd class in the Public Health Department, has been allowed to resign his post for personal motives. Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port-Said, are Major Garner, Mr. and Mme Petrococlimo, Mr. and Mme Balta, Mr. M. Balta, Mr. and Mrs. A. E Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. W. M, Cranston, Mr. H. B. Waterworth, Mr. R. 8. Ward, Mr. E. J. Chard, Mr. H. M. Anthony, Mr, C. Mavrokefalop, Mr. J. Arronfreed, Mr. G. H. Fraser, Mr. Brigstcoke, Mr. E Marten, Mr. A. J. div.head: TERRIBLE CATASTROPHE
div.p: DEVASTATING EARTHQUAKE. SAN FRANCISCO IN RUINS. INDESCRIBABLE TERROR. THOUSANDS HOMELESS. GREAT LOSS OF LIFE. San Francisco, April 18. A severe earthquake took place here to-day: buildings collapsed, canting loss of life : the dead and injured are being extricated : ‘telegraphic communication is interrupted. Considerable damage is reported from Sacra- mento. " {Reuter) San Francisco, April 18.y The town was visited by an earthquake at five o’clock this morning, which lasted for three minutes. People rushed nut into the streets in their nightdresses. The North Eastern quarter, which comprises the manufacturing and wholesale district, suffered terribly: lesser damage has been done elsewhere throughout the city. It is roughly estimated that hundreds were killed and thousands injured. Collapsing buildings ignited in all directions, and the flames threaten the whole city. Owing to a high wind and to the rupture of the gas and water mains, combating the fire is rendered most difficult: firemen are blowing np buildings in its path. Indescribable terror and excitement prevail. The five-storeyed Valencia hotel/ burying five people, and a tenement house, burying eighty in flaming mins, were the most disastrous collapses. The earthquake was felt throughout the Western States. The seismic instruments at Washington were violently agitated. {Remttrj New York, April 18. An earthquake, followed by a fire, has almost completely destroyed the town of San Francisco. A bore sank a number of ships. The whole region is devastated. It is stated that 10 OO-* people, of whom 5,000 at San Francisco, have been killed or injured. (Havas) p. {Gazette’s Special Service.) London, Thursday 10.35 a.m. Latest telegrams from New York say it is apparent that San Francisco was merely the centre of a visitation scattering min over a vast area. It is only too certain that the information as yet to hand is not complete. The town of Sanjose, 42 miles southeast of San Francisco, has been entirely wrecked. The Leland Stanford Junior University, ‘"founded fifteen years ago at Palo, 30 miles south-east of San Francisco, has been almost totally destroyed. Napa city, 36 miles north-east of San Francisco has been literally shattered by the upheaval. The damage is estimated at 300,000 dollars. The neighbouring town of Santa Roca is reported to be in flames. No particulars as to damage or loss of life are available. At Oakland, on the east side of San Francisco bay, which is a favourite resort of the inhabitants of the latter, the loss of life is comparatively insignificant. At time of cabling the entire business district of ’Frisco is reported to be in flames. The destruction of the city seems inevitable. The number of dead is estimated at a thousand and the injured probably the same. Thousands of homeless are either fleeing the city or huddling together in parks. Many prominent Americans are subscribing to funds which are being organised for the relief of the sufferers.

div.head: SERVIAN CABINET CRISIS
div.p: Belgrade, April 18. The Servian Cabinet has resigned owing to the King’s refusal to dismiss the regicides. {Reuter)

div.head: EXPLOSION ON H.M.S PRINCE OF WALES
div.p: London, April 18. An explosion took place on the battleship Prince of Wales during the speed trials in the mediterranean ; three stokers were killed and four injured. {Reuter)

div.head: TORPEDO BOAT SUNK
div.p: London, April 18. During the manoeuvres in the Mediterranean the destroyer Ardent rammed the torpedo boat No. 84, which sank. The crew were red. ' {Reuter)

div.head: THE TABAH DISPUTE
div.p: ENGLAND AND TURKEY. OPINION IN CONSTANTINOPLE. (from our Correspondent). Suez, Wednesday. The cruiser Nour El Bahr is expected to return to Suez from Akaba in a day or two. She will return shortly afterwards with provisions and stores forH.M.8. Diana. A Constantinople correspondent of "Al Lewa” writes:—"When one reads the European papers one is almost persuaded that important negotiations are being carried on between Turkey and England with reference to the question of Akaba and the occupation of Tabah by the Turkish troops. This is absolutely untrue for the Sublime Porte does not recognise that England has any concern in the matter and has therefore neither written on the subject to the Foreign Office nor to the British Ambassador. In consideration of the interests which England has in Egypt the Grand Vizier was willing to enter into a non- official conversation on this subject with the Ambassador of that Power; he would have done as much for any other Ambassador. "Great surprise is expressed here at the complete surrender of the Khedivial Government to the English. Why were the Khedivial statesmen silent when the English offered Massowah to Italy and deprived Egypt of Harrar, Zeila, and Berberah 1 What would be the answer of the Khedivial Government it the Sublime Porte asked questions to morrow concerning- these districts that form a part of Egypt for about the Sudan Treaty that was signed by the Minister of Foreign Affairs j Submission to the English' has had black consequences when pushed to such a length. "We must also combat an insinuation made by the Occupation Press—the "Progress” for example—which pretends to consider the letter written by Lord Cromer on April 13, 1892, to the Egyptian Minister of Foreign Affairs, limiting the Egyptian frontier by a line drawn from a point E of El Areash to the head of the Gulf of Akaba, as proof of the erroneousness of the Porte’s claims in the present dispute.” b WILL ARBITRATION BE RESORTED TO ? The "Magdeburger Zeitung," whose close relations with the German Foreign Office are well known, publishes, "on excellent diplomatic authority,” the astounding information that the British Government is disposed to refer the dispute with Turkey regarding Akaba to the Hague Tribunal. The “Magdeburger Zeitnng” makes four definite statements ; firstly, that the "Little, Englander” party within the British Cabinet, which objects on principle to a dispute regarding a "worthless trip of desert land,” has gained the upper hand over the Imperialist section, and caused steps to be taken for submitting the controversy to the Hague Tribunal ; secondly, that the British Government desires that Turkey, as the weaker party in the dispute, shall initiate a proposal, and submit it for controversy at the Hague, to which Great Britain would then assent; thirdly, that the British Government, availing itself of the good services of the German Government, purposes bringing about an arrangement of the dispute by arbitration; and fourthly, that the German Ambassador at Constantinople has already initiated diplomatic negotiations to arrange the necessary preliminaries for arbitration.

div.head: EASTER SERVICES
div.p: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, RAMLEH. The services on Easter Day were numerously attended. The Holy Communion was celebrated three times, at 7.30 a.m., 8.30 a m., and at noon. The services were conducted by the Rev. R. F. Rynd, B.A., assistant chaplain, and the Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., celebrated at 8.80 a.m. and preached the sermon at evensong. The musical parts of the services were rendered by an efficient choir. Mrs. A. R. Brown presided at the organ for the morning service, and Miss. Alderson for the evening service, and it was largely owing to their efforts and skill that both choir and congregation acquitted themselves so well. Ad Easter carol by Field was sang before the service. The pretty little church at Ramleh, which lends itself so well to floral decoration. presented a very festive appearance on Easter Day. Everything was done in excellent taste and much care had evidently been spent by those who made themselves responsible for the decorations. Among those who sent plants and flowers are the following—Mmes. Allen, Alderson, S. H. Carver, P. W Carver, F Haselden, Moss, G. A. Williams, Miss Wells, and Judge Sandars. Among the decorators were Mmes. R. J. Moss, B. Moss, P. W. Carver, Dickson, Misses Allen, Carver, V. Alderson, and Wells. The offerings for the Poor Fund at the early celebrations amounted to P.T. 287. The collections at 11 a.m. and 6.80 p.m. amounted to P.T. 4104 4/’0 and were presented by the church committee to the clergy aa an Easter offering.

div.head: THE DEWEY AT PORT SAID
div.p: ARRIVAL OF FLOATING DOCK. (From oUr CorrEspoNdent.) Port Said, Thursday. The American floating drydock Dewey arrived here last night on her way to the Philippines, and anchored in the roads. The drydock is towed by the cruisers Caesar, Brutus, and Glacier and convoyed by the Tacoma, which was recently at Alexandria. The latter left the Dewey 250 miles from Port Said and arrived here on Tuesday, being in constant communication with the drydock by means of wireless telegraphy. It is stated that the dues to be paid for the passage of the drydock through the canal will amount to £20,000. Port Said, Thursday, Later. The drydock Dewey entered the canal this morning in tow of tugs.

div.head: CONSTITUTION FOR EGYPT
div.p: "OUR GREAT OBJECT AND HOW TO ATTAIN IT.” Under the above heading "Al Lewa” publishes the following :— "Genuine Egyptian patriots have greeted with joy the open letter published by "Al Moayad” and submitted fay Sayei el Bakri to the Prince of Wales. Some would have preferred that the Sayed should have submitted his plea to the British Parliament and the entire world, bat they fail to recognise that the publication of this open letter in the “Moayad” has a spiritual meaning—it is to render our leaders more zealous to fulfil this important task. El Bakri has only prepared the way for them. "We should therefore abandon the task of hair-splitting and consecrate ourselves to the fulfilment of our most sacred duties. It is no disgrace to us to remind the English of the programme drawn up for us by Lord Dufferin. We ought not to blame the British Government for the harmful policy followed in Egypt for that Government only receives its information from the reports of Lord Cromer, who has every interest in remaining absolute master of Egypt. We have only ourselves to blame, for not one of ns attempts to bring the complaints of the country before official and other circles in London. "To sum np, we should appoint a deputation of the notables of the country and instruct them to lay the demands of the Egyptian nation before the British statesmen in England — if we ever wish to arrive at our goal.

div.head: FASHIONABLE WEDDING
div.p: One of the prettiest weddings which have lately been celebrated in Alexandria took place in St. Mark’s Church yesterday, when Miss Mary Smith, daughter of Mr. W. H. Smith, of Mustapha, was married to Mr. J. Hubbalday Barton, of Alexandria. The officiating clergyman was the Rev. Canon Ward, M.A., Mr. 0.8. Heaton presiding at the organ. The church was most tastefully decorated with white flowers and palms for the occasion. The bride looked charming in an exquisite robe of Brussels lace over white Liberty satin made up upon taffetas. The gown was artistically trimmed with chiffon and sprays of orange blossom, the chiffon forming a gathered tablier, and deep frill round the skirt and train ; the corsage and elbow sleeves were arranged with chiffon caught op here and there by sprays of orange blossom. The bride wore an embroirdered tulle veil with a tiara of orange blossoms, and carried a lovely shower bouquet of white exotics tied with long white satin streamers. Her long Court train lavishly lined with chiffon was carried by two little train-bearers, the Misses Connie and Freda Hind, wearing pale bine Sarah silk frocks and large silk hats trimmed with chiffon and ribbon to match. They each wore pretty gold heart-shaped lockets studded with pearls attached to a fine gold chain, the gifts of the bridegroom. The two bridesmaids, the Misses Emma and Nellie Smith (sisters of the bride) wore white voile dresses with large white hats, and carried bouquets. They wore the gifts of the bridegroom, Miss Emma Smith a gold watch, and Miss Nellie Smith a gold pendant and chain. The bride was given away by her father, and the bridegroom was supported by Mr. H. E. C. Moss as best man. After the ceremony a reception was held at the New Khedivial Hotel, which was largely attended. The health of the newly-wedded pair was proposed by Mr. R. J. Moss and responded to with cheers. The happy young couple left at 4 p.m. for their honeymoon. The bride’s travelling dress was a tailor-made costume of fine dark grey doth trimmed with dark green silk galon, and a most becoming hat trimmed with roses. The costume was rendered complete by a handsome long white ostrich feather stole. The presents were both numerous and costly, among them the following Bridegroom to bride, diamond ring and cheque ; bride to bridegroom, silver crested punch bowl and tray with twelve silver goblets and ladle to match ; Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Smith, silver crested canteen ; Mr., W. Smith, pair silver breakfast crusts and silver eggetand and spoons; Mr. C. div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: MOUNTED INFANTRY FOOTBALL LEAGUE. » COWAN’S BENEFIT MATCH. (From a Correspondent). Teams representing No. 1 section M. I. Inniskillings, and No. 2 section M. I. Royal Berkshire Regiment met at Abbasaieh in a friendly match in aid of Cowan’s benefit. The teams were : R. Inniskillings—goal, Magowan ; backs, Prichard and McDaid ; halves. Jenkins, Brown, and Kilday; forwards, Magee, Hamilton, Cowan, (Capt.), Henery, and Edens. R. Berks —goal, Parker; backs, Bishop and Paveley ; halves, Beasley, Ewatt, and Grubb ; forwards, Webb, Moreland, Raymond, True sell, Lan- gridge (Capt.) Almost 2,500 spectators were present when Captain Cowan, having won the toss, decided to defend the city goal Ray mend kicked off for the Berks and play was around Magowan and company, but the custodian saved the situation and play was transferred, only for a moment however, as the Berks were once more operating round Magowan. A good shot from the toe of Raymond was well saved bat he had to acknowledge defeat' at the hands of Trassell, the ball finding the corner of the net amid deafening cheers. On resuming the Inniskillings took play in hand. The representatives of the Shamrock had very hard lines in not equalising, one shot of Cowan’s striking the upright Play for a while remained around Bishop and company until a handball against Jenkins relieved the pressure. Midfield play now followed until Hamilton broke away and giving the sphere to Mages the latter dodged well and gave a splendid chance to Cowan, who made the cross bar shake in the attempt to score. Give-and-take play followed. Webb then got away on a dashing run bat McDaid robbed and play was around Bishop and company. Great was the excitement that now prevailed, Henery missing the post by inches. The Berks scored again bat the goal was on offside one. The Inniskillings then advanced, Elens leading the group. The Skillings were pressing when a handball against Langridge put them in a good position. The free kick was entrusted to Magee, who with a terrific grasshopper sent in the equalising goal amidst tremendous cheers. The game after thin was very exciting. Close on halftime Jenkins had hard lines in not adding to the soon, which remained one goal each. The first item of importance in the second half was a dashing ran down the touch-line by Jenkins. He centred well to Hamilton hot the latter hung on the leather too long and a, glorious chance was lost The Berks now found their feet Two corners in succession were awarded to them but soon they could not as the custodian was in fine form. The Skillings now played up and Kilday was seen to advantage. After dodging a couple of opponents he gave to Henery, who with a fast cross-shot was nearly giving his side the lead, the ball finding the back of the net Both teams were now completely done np. Play was somewhat slack until Magowan got away on a good ran and gave the sphere to Hamilton, who sent past On the kickoff the Berks took play in hand, Webb and Raymond being very prominent On the right Webb was very dangerous when Prichard robbed and play went in favour of the Inniskillings, hot they could not add to their score owing to fine defence play by Bishop and company. The “Burly ’Un” was in fine fettle and saved the citadel when all seemed lost The best run of the match so, f*r was done by Edens, bat his parting shot went wide. Play after this was in favour of the Berks, but fine goal-keeping by Cowan kept them out With only four minutes to go both teams played desperately, Trassell, Langridge, Webb, and Grubb having shots at goal, but all to no purpose as Cowan was not to be caught napping. Both goals were visited in turn but no advantage was gained. Just on call of time Parker brought off a neat save. Shortly after, the referee’s whistle Bounded for fall/ time, leaving the game a draw and one of the most exciting games ever seen at Abbaasieh. div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE
div.p: (Communication Officielle) La Commission Mnnioipale s'est réunie le 18 avril 1906 à 4 h. p.m an palais mnnioipal sons la présidence de 8.E. Monstapba Pacha Ibadi Le Vice Président, an nom de l’assemblée entière, souhaite la bienvenue à S.E. Monstapha Ibadi Pacha, nouveau Gouverneur d’Alexandrie et Président de la Commission Mnnioipale. 11 ajoute qu’Ibadi Pacha n’est pas un inconnu pour les Alexandrins et surtout pour la Municipalité, car à titre de sous-gouverneur de la Ville, il a déjà pris part aux débuts de l’Insti tution. Familier avec le rouage mnnioipal, la haute collaboration de Son Excellence ne peut qu’être des plus utiles et la Ville doit en augurer le plus de bien. S.E. Ibadi Pacha remeroie le Vice-Président de ses bonnes paroles et se félicite de se te trouver encore une fois dans cette enceinte ; tous ses efforts, ajoute-t-il, seront consacrés an .bien et à la prospérité de la Ville. Sur une observation de M. Kingham, il e, t , décidé que les projets de procès-verbaux de la Commission seront, oomme oela se pratiqae pour la Délégation, vélocigraphiés et distribués aux membres avant la séanoe suivante où lenr approbation doit avoir lieu. . A la même occasion, quelques membres croient utile de mentionner au oompte-rendu, étant donnée son importance, une proposition qui avait été faite à la dernière séanoe par M. Rothaoker tendant à oe que, au lieu d’aliéner définitivement les terrains dn quai, il conviendrait de les louer pour 99 ans moyennant une rente fonoière invariable. , Communication est, donnée d’une lettre du 28 mars de Mr. Amb. A. Ralli remerciant In ,, Commission pour la lettre qu’elle lui a adressés , . à l’oocasion de l’expiration de. son mandat de r Vice-Président. Il est également donné connaissance d’une, lettre du 29 mare 1906 de S.E. le Ministre de l’Intérjeur demandant de tenir en suspens la délibération de la Commission du 21 mars re lative à la mise en venta des terrains des quais, en attendant que les services qu’il a consultés an sujet de oette question lui aient, fait pat- venir leurs réponses. (A Suivre)

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourdhui à midi et demie) Comme on pouvait s’y attendre, les nouvelles émissions, Cairo-Heliopolis, Banque d’Orient, eto. exeroent une iofluenoe défavorable sur notre marché pat. le drainage de l’argent au quel elles ont donné lieu. , Ce motif joint au malaise aotnel des bonrses européennes oocasionne ici une réaction plus on moins générale. En somme on est vendeur sur presque toute la ligne, sans rencontrer d’aohetenre. Les seules valeurs qui ont donné lieu ce matin à un échange suivi sont l'Agricole, la .Sait and Soda, la Delta Land, et le Trust. L’Agrioole olôture à 10 8/16, la Delta Land à 4 23/32, le Trust à 1 19/32 et la Sait and , Soda à 95. > On offre,la Delta Light à 12 15/16. Il est probable qne la oota reprendra dès la remise en circulation des sommes importantes immobilisées par les nouvelles émissions et la ioonolusion.de l’empruDt russe. L’Agrioole, entre antres, fait preuve d’nne ,i fermeté de bon augure.

div.head: CIRCULAIRE H. DE VRIES ET BOURIGNY
div.p: Le Caire, Mercredi 18 Avril. Le taux de l’eeoompte libre h Londres vient d’être réd«itdel/8à 8 1/8. Hier, au Stook Bxohange, le Consolidé et l’Unifiéa soit restés invariés à 91 et 106 1/4. La National Bank At l'Agnnnl* nnf r0g&^ 1/8 à 97 1/1 ftt. U> 1/4. La Daïra est demeurée inchangée à 18 1/4. La Delta Light a perdu 1/8 à 13 1 /8 A Paris, le 'Crédit Foncier Egyptien a clô 1 taré en réaotion de 2 francs à 783 et lu Banque d’Athènes de 1 franc à 153. • * * Rassuré par les nouvelles relatives à l’emprunt russe, ainsi que par les cours fermes de Londres, notre marché à montré, oe matin, moins d’indécision et pins d’activité qu’hier, notamment snr’les grandes valeurs. Toutefois on a été quelque pen faibles en clôture. La National Bank a été, un moment, demandée à 27 1/8 pour clôturer au même prix, vendenrs. Mouvementée et en bonne tendance, l’Agrieole a avancé à 10 9/32 pour clôturer à 10 1/4 >; suivant toutes les apparanoes, on ne tardera pas à voir des ooura meilleurs. Le Comptoir Financier s’est inscrit à 8 3/16. La Banque d’Orient est revenue à 147. Le Crédit Fonoier a été ramené à 790. La Delta Light a reoulé à 13 1/16. La Nile Land a faibli à 18 6/8. te Bon eourant d’affaires eu Héliopolis, dont • d’action a été poussée à 865 pou» tomber à 845 ; la part de fondateur a fini à 13 3/4 après avoir atteint 14 3/4. L’action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux est revenue à 4 7/16 ; la part de fondateur à 85. Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovioh ont été offerts à 18 1/4, malgré l’augmentation de oapital votée hier par suite de l’achat dn Mena House et en vue de l’agrandissement du Savoy. Les Upper ont fléchi à 4 7/8-15/J 6, Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été échangés à 4 7/8 pour olôturer à 4 13/16. LesHooker se sont maintenus à 1 1/8 t-3/16. Les Bâtâtes, moins fermes qu’hier, ont clôturé à 2 1/8; les New Egyptien à 32 sb. ; les S .lt and Soda à 24 sh. 9 après avoir atteint 25 et baissé à 23 sh. 9 ; les Oasis à 1 1/4. Les Qlymenoponlo ont été demandés à 1 f—21/32. Des £2,000,000 .'d’obligations S'1/2 peur œnt, récemment émisés par 1 Agricultural Bank of Egypt, 1,500,000 ont été placées de suite à Londres au pair. Le restant sera placé en Novembre proobain. ( . L’opération est très avantageuse pour les actions, car un million et quart de la somme est déjà prê'ée à 9 % aux cultivateurs et on peut dès lors compter sur un meilleur dividende pour l’execioe prochain. Tout en favorisant les notions, l’augmentatioD du capital obligations avantage, dans une plus forte mesure enoore, les parts de fondateur. Celles ci reçoivent, en effet, 50 % des bénéfices, déduotion faite de l’intérêt payé aux notions, fraie et autres charges statutaires. D’autre part, la réserve, qui s’accroît d’année en année, leur revient, oomme on sait, à moitié en cas de dissolution. Il faut donc s’attendre dans l’avenir à une augmentation considérable du dividende afférent à ces parts, au nombre de 2,000 en tout. Leur valeur pourrait atteindre un ooura extraordinairement élevé, surtout si on les subdivisait un jour en dixième, C6 qui rendrait le titre plus léger et plus maniable. • • # Ufl La souscription publique aux aotions de l’Express Nile Steamers Co. a été ouverte oe matin à l’Anglo-Egyptian Bank ; elle sera clôturés demain soir. Il est alloué une part de fondateur pour chaque oioq aotions ordinaires. Nous restons à la disposition de oeux de nos olients qui voudraient souscrire par notre entremise. Assemblées extraordinaires : L’assemblée de la Nnngovioh Hotels Co., tonne hier an Caire, a approuvé la proposition dn conseil tendant à l’angmentation dn oapital social et, par suite, à la modification de l’art. 5 des Statuts. Il sera émis, an prix del2£. 9,500 aotions nonvelles de la valeur nominale de £ 4, qui seront réservées aux actionnaires aotuels, à raison de 1 aotion nouvelle oontre 3 anciennes. Le oapital de la Sooiété, qui était ffe £110,000, se trouvera ainsi porté i à £ 148, o:o. ■ .. D’autre part l’assemblée de la Wardan Esta te, tenue hier au Caire, a sanctionné le projet I d’élévation du oapital social à £ 150,000 par l’émission de 10,000 aotions ordinaires nouvelles de £5, qoi seront émises au pair. * * * Les cours du coton sont signalés en reprise d’Amérique. Hier, le Mai a gagné 10 points et l’Octobre 7. Le disponible est resté invarié. Les arrivages à New York ont été de 49,000 i balles contre 82,000. Le marché de Liverpool est pins on moins stationnaire. » Ici, le Mai, qni a olôtnré hier soir à 22 7/16 sur des réalisation s,a ouvert, oe matin, à 22 5/16 pour finir en olôture à 21 13/16. REMERCIEMENTS La famille dn regretté Félix Snares, profon dément tonohée des témoignages de sympathie qu’elle a reçus à l'occasion de la perte orneUe qu’elle vient de faire, nous prie d’exprimer sa pins sinoère reconnaissance à tontes les personnes qni ont bien voula prendre part à oette douloureuse épreuve.

div.p: L’Administration a l’honneur de porter à la connaissance du pubii », qu’elle recevra jusqu'au Samedi 5 Mai 1906 'des offres pour -la- fourniture de 24 Tonnes Métriques d'huile d’olive pure pour graissage livrable franoo dans les Magasins de Gabbari (Alexandrie) à raison de 2C00 kilos par mois à partir du 1er Juin 1906 selon les conditions dont on peut obtenir copie aux Magasins de Bonlao et de Gabbari, contre paiement de 100 millièmes. Les offres devront être accompagnées d’une feuille .de papier timbré de 80 m/m. div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS
div.p: WILL IT BREAK UP? Berlin, April 18. The Emperor William’s telegram to Count. Golochowski continues to exercise Europe: the consensus of opinion is that it foreshadows the break up of the Triple Alliance. (Reuter,,

Berlin, April 18. Baron von Holstein, privy councillor to the German Foreign Office, has resigned. He was the secret framer of the German foreign policy for years, including the Emperor William’s visit to Morocco, and it is believed that he has been made the scapegoat for its comparative unsuccess. {Reuter) Berlin, April 18. Baron von Holstein has resigned.

VOLUNTEBRS WANTED. ju Durban, April 18. The Natal Government are ‘advertising for volurteers, to form a special corps for active service in Zululand. The pay is to be five shillings a day. Twenty three native suspects from Greytown have been sent to Pietermaritz- burg to be courtmartialled. (Reuter) Durban, April |8. The mobilisation of the whole of the militia in Natal apart from 1,0C0 irregulars is regarded as inevitable. - - {Reuter)

Paris, April 18. A serious conflict between troops and the miners took place in northers France : several officers and soldiers were injured-by stone- throwing. (Bearer) Paris, April 18. Eighteen hundred printers have left off work. M. Clemenceau has gone to Lens, where the strikers have pillaged the pavilion of the concierge attached to the mines manager. Rioting followed, and the troops drove back the strikers. Two officers were seriously wounded. (Hasas)

Athens, April 18. The King and Queen of England have arrived, and drove through the streets, among cheering crowds, to the Palace, where precessions with bands and banners paraded before King Edward, who viewed them from the balcony. (Reuter)
U.S.A. AND CHINA. Washington, April 18. President Roosevelt and the Dowager Empress of China exohanged greetings, on the oooaeion of the oompletion of the all-Amerioan cable with Shanghai. ' (Reuter)
AMERICAN INSURANCE SCANDAL8. Washington, April 18. President Roosevelt, in a message to Congress,, urges the need of special legislation to prevent the recurrence of insurance scandals. {Reuter)

IMPORTANT DIVORCE DECISION. Washington, April 18. The Supreme Court has decided that a resident of one State cannot procure a divorce from a resident of another State. This invalidates thousands of remarriages, including the cases of prominent Americans elsewhere. (R.)

PENNY POSTAGE PROPOSALS. Rome, April 18. At Thursday's sitting of the Postal Conference the representative of New Zealand with propose, and that of Egypt second, a resolutionon in favour of universal penny postage. The Japanese representative will propose a twopenny postage which is not to affect the proposed res tricted Anglo Japanese penny postage. The British officials are opposed to universal penny postage. (Neuter)
JESUIT GENERAL DEAD. Paris, April 18. Fr. Martin, General of the Jesuits, is dead. {Reuter

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: London, April 12. The Money Market. The mention of the call money rate in New York last week as being a possible disturbing factor in this market b*s been more than justified. Short loans over there have commanded about 20 % throughout the week, with the inevitable result that the exchange rates have had a violent drop, and gold has been taken from this market. Eagles to the value of half-a-million sterling were yesterday taken from the Bank of England at 76s. 8d., and should New York cheque continue to drop we shall see bar gold being shipped even at the present price of 78s., and perhaps even sovereigns. These shipments of the precious metal will no doubt lead ease; to the American stock markets, but coming at the present time, when the French cheque is standing at under 25.12, and when the Russian loan is on the verge of being launched, cannot but have a most undesirable effect upon oar money market. Luckily credit dealers have borne in mind their experience during the last few months, and have been treading warily. They have refrained from entering into long commitments, and have kept their surplus funds well ir hand, the result being that call money has sometimes been as low as 1 $ % and weekly loans 2 $ %. the latter being 2 $ %. The discount market has been influenced by like considerations ; the uncertain outlook in regard to money has naturally tended to stiffen rates of discount, and for the present, of coarse, the margin between money and discount rates is all in favour of the discount houses, to whom it would be selfish to begrndge this little boom after their experiences of the last three months. Short bills, say 30 to 60 days, naturally command better rates than three months’ bills, 3 % being the fine rate for the former, and 3 $ to 3 $ for the latter tenor. On Tuesday the London County Council I offer for tender 2} millions six months’ bills, and the average rate which they secure, vis., 3 %, does not indicate any immediate prospect of very cheap money. The question now is how much gold will America need to satisfy her requirements. Should the sum of one to two millions sterling not suffice, then we must look forward to troublesome times in this market. The rate of exchange, however, to-day is a little firmer, which of course is a very hopeful sign. 7 The Steak Markets. There is quite a rosy look in the share 'market, and the uncertainties of legislation of the present Government is the Only unpleasant feature to be reckoned with. Even this is beginning to appear less terrible in view of the various climbs-down Ministers have thought fit to make It is true that the public has not yet come in, but the heavy dividends which are being distributed in almost all classes of security must call for investment ere long, and there is reason to suppose that at present prices shares are well held. As regards the Egyptian market, this has been a feature this week in consequence of the meeting of the Estatei Company, whose chairman, Mr. Greville Palmer, who is -chairman also of the Bank of Egypt* made a point of dissipating the absurd fears as regards the solidity if things Egypt**”- We have before pointed out the foolishness of supposing that the number of > small Egyptian issues have in any way been Over-done. Indeed, the aggregate capital of the whole of these investment companies would not the sufficient to buy two or three large villages, and from the point of view of developing Egypt as a whole the capital issued at present is entirely inadequate. Mr. Palmer alluded to a point which has been painfully clear to those who know most of Egypt, namely, that foreign countries have taken a far more intelligent view of the great future prospects of Egypt than has been taken by the British- public, and on that account this country is losing a large number of splendid investments which should have naturally fallen to them. Mr. Lang Anderson mentioned that owing to the natives being encouraged by the Mohamedan religion to put their money only in laud, investments of the nature must always be on a specially solid foundation by reason of the constant demand ; and whereas the native investor formerly expected a return of 10% to 12% in land investments, he is glad to-day to invest at a basis of 6% to 7%. This cause alone is probably sufficient to account for the general rise that has taken place, and to ensure stability and probable farther rise in prices of agricultural land generally, with a very considerable prospect of farther large profits on lands under improvement. Consol In the early part of the week Consols were offered, the reason for which was said to be connected with the projected new issues. In consequence the price fell somewhat, hut the market is now steadier, and the price to-night, 90 j for cash and 90| for the account, shows little change on the week, Foreign Bends. The completion of the arrangements for the new Russian loan has kept the international market rather dull, and there is little prospect of any important business being done until | this is out of the way. Japanese have perhaps been the best feature, one or two of the issues having shown a slight advance. The Four-percents are now 92, a rife of | on our last quotation. Russians close at 83. Home Railways. ' The glorious weather conditions and the l excellent prospects for good holiday earnings

have given some encouragement to investors to patronise this market, and a moderate amount of business has been done. The traffic returns are again very satisfactory, the Great Eastern having an increase of £4,600, and if the weather continues favourable over the week end, we should have some gratifying returns next week, which may have the effect of restoring confidence in home railway stocks. Americans. Scarcity of money in New York and heavy selling in Wall Street have resulted in lees dealings here, and the prices in several of the leading shares are down on the week. Union Pacifics had a somewhat sharp reaction after the boom last week, and leave off at 162 $. Pennsylvania shares are rather better, bat Canadian Pacifica are unchanged. The dosing prices are as follow: Aitchison, 96 fid ; Baltimore and Ohio,117|xd; Canadian Paoifio,178 J; Chicago and Milwaukee, 189 $; Brie, 46 f; Illinois Central, 179$; Louisville, 164$; New York, Central, 148$; Pennsylvania 8harae, 73; Philadelphia and Reading, 71 $; Southern Pacific, 711; Steel Common, 44$; Pref, 112 A. Mining. The official report of Mr. Churchill's speech on* South Africa, which was telegraphed to Johannesburg, seems to have been fairly well received in that country, and has dispelled certain misunderstandings with regard to the Government’s intentions. A more confident tone has prevailed this week in the mining market, and several of the favourite South African shares have been in demand. Rand Mines dose at 6 J and East Rands at 5 $. The returns of the gold output from the Transvaal for March are again highly satisfactory, the total being of the value of £1,884.815, an increase of £153,151 over the preceding month. This constitutes a "record,” in that it exceeds by 12,129 ounces the previous highest output since the war, i.e., that of last December. A statement of the output for the seven months, September. 1905, to March of the present year, shows a steady increase, and everything connected with the industry is favourable to a period of great prosperity, providing there is no undue interference on the part of the Government. The Egyptian mining market seems altogether more favourably looked up in. Egyptian Options were at the beginning greatly in demand, and the price advanced to 2. Yesterday, however, they suffered a relapse, and dose at l}-$. Nile Valleys are firmer at 8s. There are no other changes to report. Egyptians. The rise in Delta Land and Investment has continued since our last, and the price has been as high as 5$ buyers, but tor the moment support seems to have been withdrawn, and they are easier at 4$. Land and General Trust have also been largely bought at 3/16 premium, but buyers seem to get all they want at this price. National Bank of Egypt are steady at 27$, and Agricultural* at 10$. Delta light Railway Preference have been bought np to 3$, and the Deferred have been enquired for round about 11. Bank of Abyssinia at $ premium and Union Foncihre at 6$ are unchanged, and there is no business doing in them. Daira Ord. are slightly easier at 18$ and Deferred at 106. Egyptian Estates are very firm at 2$ and the Deferred at 13. Egyptian Markets are bid for at 1 9/32, but Salt said Soda are sellers at about 24s. Trust and Investment at § premium, and Land Banks at 9$ are the same.

Hadow, Lincolnshire Regiment, has been formally seconded lor service with the Egyptian Army. In the coming August, Lieutenant J. R., Bassett, Royal Berks Regiment, will vacate the adjutancy of the 2nd Battalion on the completion of the regulation three years. It is intimated that when the 2nd Batialion Royal Berks Regiment leaveq Khartoum in the next trooping season for India, it will be stationed in Snbathn. Subathd Is ten miles from Simla, the headquarters of the Indian Viceroy and Anglo-Indian society daring the hot season. The garrison of 8nhathn usually consists of a battalion of British infantry and some detachments. It is a fairly healthy station. . \ The third class cruiser Perseus will be shortly re-comnfthaioned at Port Said for another commission on the Bast Indies Station.

div.head: NOTICE
div.p: The General Administration of the Wakfs informs the public Wit it possesses at Alexandria lands of a superficies of about 18 feddans situated on the bank of the El Farkha Canal, which fetched at the last adj udioation the price of L.E. 24,500. The Superior Board of the Wakfs Administration having ordered the Bale by acotion of the said lands by way of exchange, the Administration will receive offers on Sunday, 29th April, 1906, from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., at the offices of the Wakfs Administration, Bab-el- Lonk, Cairo, for the renewal of the anotion above-mentioned. All persons wishing to take part in this adjudication may see the lists of bids at the offices of the aministration and make an offer, which must be accompanied by 20% of the total amount in ratio to the above price. The Administration reserves the right to refuse or accept any offer, without giving the reason.

Ordre du Jour: 1. ) To consider the terms on which The Egyptian Salt and Soda Company Limited in principle are agreed to take over or amalgamate with the undertaking of the Port Said Salt Association Limited. 2. ) To ascertain whether the majority of the said Meeting are willing or not to accept with or without any modification the terms herein above referred to. 8.) In the event of the majority of the said Meeting being willing to accept such terms as aforesaid: To consider and if thought fit to pass the following resolution: “That the prohibition contiained in Article 93 of the Articles of Association of the Company, restraining a Director from voting in respect of any contract or arrangement in which he is interested or therein mentioned, be suspended (bat only in respect of any matter or matters in any way connected with or arising at of the business hereinabove referred to) until such prohibition shall have been reimposed by a subsequent General Meeting : and so that daring the suspension of such prohibition any Director or Directors so interested, may vote is respect of any such matter or matters, and his or their vote or votes shall be counted.
